Today’s significant outperformance for Canadian cannabis stocks, led by Tilray (TLRY) and no news for the industry, at one point
pushed the total market capitalization for Canadian Licensed Producers above $C 80 billion before closing at $C 73 billion. The
top 22 Canadian cannabis stocks are up 127% in stock price appreciation since August 15 (S&P 500 +3.1%) and have added $C
41 billion in total value in that time. Excitement is building as Canada prepares to be the first developed market to legalize cannabis for
recreational use (October 17). We estimate an addressable Canadian market of $C 10 billion (wholesale $C 5 billion). The $C 73 billion market
capitalization in relation to a total market opportunity worth roughly $C 5 billion in value is difficult to fathom. Clearly, valuations require global
opportunities to be realized, though we question the pace of development and degree of advantage for these companies.

#REF! hello good morning
ESM @ BE one might wonder why Pivateer does not lend shares out... or do they do that on purpose hey? I mean 600% fee last seen u would if you could, unless u had other reasons not to
BE11:21am

Headlines around the world suggest other governments are taking a more constructive stance toward cannabis including
Germany which has embraced medical marijuana, the United Kingdom, and South Africa. While we value the Canadian retail
market at $C 10 billion ($C 5 billion) and the U.S. at roughly $50 billion, the total global category could reach upwards of $200
billion as suggested by Constellation Brands. In this context, assuming the Canadian companies move globally and win business in
markets across the world, perhaps these valuations could be viewed as more palatable. While the Canadian Licensed Producers have an
edge in attacking global market opportunities, they do not have, in our view, a definitive global first mover advantage even as the companies
are providing exports throughout the world. We believe any country that embraces cannabis legalization, in any form, will also likely look
to create local jobs potentially favoring local production (requiring capital) or local companies (requiring partnerships for the Canadian
producers). Government action will likely be slow and deliberate; even Canada, which had a commercial system for medical marijuana
and a ruling party that was focused on lifting prohibition as part of its platform, took deliberate action that delayed the process.

Waterloo Thing is what's the barrier to entry? It's often called grass for a reason. It's very easy to grow.

On June 25, the FDA approved GW Pharmaceuticals's Epidiolex (cannabidiol or CBD) for the treatment of two ultra rare forms of epilepsy: Dravet syndrome and Lennox-Gastaut syndrome. Launch of Epidiolex is contingent upon the Drug Enforcement Agency (DEA) rescheduling the therapy in order to allow it to be used for medicinal use, which was expected to take place within 90 days of the FDAs decision or by ~September 23. We expect the rescheduling will be a catalyst for GW Pharmaceuticals's shares as it should enable the launch of the first FDA approved cannabinoid-based therapy.

Waterloo @tom dalgleish, maybe but it's a weed in many countries and is easy to grow with considerable consistency. Little barrier to entry. GW slightly different in being a biotech and doing FDA trials.
BE11:27am

Basically, the DEA has two switch its classification from Schedule I (addictive, bad) to Schedule IV (not addictive, potentially good).

wayneJ Is it me or does it feel like the last days of Rome with increasing insanity and debauchery? All we need now is for Trump to appoint a horse as his successor.

BE11:30am

We believe that Epidiolex is a potential blockbuster therapy for the
treatment of epilepsy. In clinical studies, Epidiolex proved safe and effective for ultra rare epilepsy disorders, contributing to a reduction in the frequency of seizures in PhIII trials for both Dravet and Lenox-Gastaut syndromes. Both syndromes together account for 20K+ patients in the U.S. While revenues would first come from these two initial indications, physicians who treat epilepsy are accustomed to prescribing therapies for unlabeled seizure indications. As such, we expect physicians to drive long term sales growth for the Epidiolex franchise through off label usage in other indications such as tuber sclerosis complex (TSC) and general cortical dysplasia. All together, pediatric epilepsy accounts for ~400K+ patients in the U.S. A growing dataset – that will include data from a PhIII study for TSC which is to be released 1H19 – will likely reinforce this behavior. Epidiolex is currently under regulatory review by the EMA in Europe and should launch 1Q19. We project 2019E sales of $72M, growing to $1.3B by 2025E.

As a result, we are increasing our sales forecast by 5% to £215m and PBT by 7% to £62m. We continue to expect profits to be lower than last year
due to lower gross margin (mix & capacity expansion) and higher operating costs (new openings, investment and higher wages). Games Workshop has also announced a 35p dividend, which is similar to the dividend announced this time last year and reflects the cash flow in the period. We are increasing our target price to 3,250p to reflect greater confidence in the longterm outlook.

The auction procedure will consist of a maximum of three rounds which will all take place on 22 September 2018. 

BE11:40am

In the first round, only the offeror with the lowest offer as at the commencement of the auction (or, in the event of both offers being at the same price, the last offeror to revise) may make an increased bid. 

BE11:40am

In the second round, only the offeror that was not eligible to make a bid in the first round may make an increased bid (and it may do so even if no increased bid was made in the first round by the other offeror).

We continue to believe that control of Sky is strategically critical for Disney's global DTC business, that it can afford to overpay, and that through Fox, Disney will end up with Sky. We expect Fox, with Disney's approval, will raise its bid for Sky to at least match Comcast's (CMCSA:$36.96-NR) £14.75 offer.

wayneJ Can Disney refuse to sell to Comcast?
11:45 am
BE11:45am

Disney has strategically reorganized into four divisions including the recently formed "Direct-to-Consumer (DTC) AND International" division. DIS will have a DTC business in the US and Asia and Sky offers a DTC service in seven of the largest European countries. We assume plan B would be to strike a deal with the local cable or telephone operators, but DIS's preference has to be a DTC offering. In the grand scheme of a $100 billion strategic acquisition of Fox and the balance of Sky (before the divestiture of the RSNs), we do not think Disney will pause on a 1£ raise for Sky, which equates to about $1.4 billion.

BE11:55am

The good news is that R Tisci is proving through the breadth of this offering that he is cognizant of the broad appeal of the Burberry brand. He appears to be embracing the breadth and size of the Burberry brand and the responsibilities that go with it vs the more niche fashion-forward brand he was head designer for before (Givenchy). The bad news is that in trying to please everyone he might be losing out on the brand new messages. In our experience, brand turnarounds typically reduce SKUs and concentrate brand messages on fewer key pieces before re-expanding the breadth of the offer (in year 2). This is not what Burberry and R Tisci did in this first collection. Did Tisci play too safe or as WWD put it in its show review ‘too ambitious’ by wanting to please all? Will imminent peer fashion shows at other luxury fashion houses out-stage him in share of voice having diluted somewhat his message? Recall that Paris fashion week is hosting in a few days Hedi Slimane’s grand fashion return at Celine. Burberry’s daywear classic looks, to us, were also possibly too easy to copy by mass market fashion contenders.

PBateman Anyone have thoughts on Kier's results this morning? Shorters to cover in the coming weeks or keep the positions rolling?

BE11:57am

Burberry is not the next Gucci, but does that really come as a surprise? We don’t think so, given: a) The traditional Burberry customer. While the company expects its client base to evolve towards a more fashion-forward crowd, the new designer probably did not want to alienate the current customer base. b) Top management are LVMH alumni, with the LVMH culture focused on brand protection and respect for brand DNA, thus not conducive to an overly aggressive style at Burberry. c) Low guidance, with the company calling for flat sales at cc for two years and an only fairly modest (for now factored into SGe) acceleration in the pace of growth to the high single digits by 2021-22 (upside risk, in our view).

BE12:00pm

Here's Cannacord.

BE12:01pm

Kier has delivered a set of results in line with expectations for FY2018 with no big surprises. Underlying EPS, DPS and average net debt of £375m were all as expected; there were no exceptional items. The focus today will be on the additional information given in relation to the Future Proofing Kier programme, which is streamlining the group. There is a clear target to reduce average net debt to £250m by FY2021 and be in a reported net cash position by that time. This will be supported by delivering incremental free-cash of at least £20m as well as c.£30-50m of disposals. The outlook comments point to good trading and visibility in the group's core markets with the order book up strongly. Kier has consistently delivered decent margins in its core Services and Construction businesses and streamlining the group (taking out layers of management costs, IT benefits, etc.) should further support margins going forward. We expect no changes to underlying consensus for FY2019 but a c.+10% increase in underlying profits for FY2020 and net debt trajectory is clear to FY2021. These results and incremental comments on the plans to reduce net debt should assuage some of the fears around the balance sheet and assuming the macro backdrop holds up, the benefits should start to show through from FY2020. With the dividend yield at c.7% and EBITDA multiple at c.7 times, the shares should be supported by these results and comments.

PBateman Big divi to keep paying out..
PBateman Had to laugh on the analysts call this morning, 'have you considered trimming the dividend to get net debt down faster?''
12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

"Short covering" is something that appears in market reports a lot more than it actually happens, judging by the relative stability of the lending data. It takes a serious change of circumstances -- such as with Ocado, or Autonomy -- to make people eat the loss.

PBateman ''The dividend is very important to our investor base. I appreciate the yield looks high, but I'd rather get the share price up to correct this as opposed to cutting the dividend''
BE12:03pm

Stifel also.

BE12:03pm

A good prelim statement with headline numbers in line with expectations and colour provided on the Future Proofing Kier programme (FPK). The programme is expected to drive incremental additional annual profits and FCF of at least £20m in FY20, and also targets £30-50m of non-core disposals. The group now targets average net debt of £250m in FY21 (vs FY18A £375m) and a year-end net cash position in FY21, driven by good cash generation and the disposals. We view this as a significant positive given the market's focus on the group's leverage. Incorporating the impact of FPK would see us increase our FY20E operating profit forecast by c.10%. We view Kier as an attractive investment proposition given our expectation of improving earnings quality, a step-up in cash generation and reducing leverage. An attractive dividend yield of over 6.5% underpins our investment case.

There remain many moving parts and many strings to Kier's bow and all are moving in the right direction with strong performance from Property and Residential and a stable position in Construction, that Construction did not move backwards is a good result in our view given the current challenges in the UK construction markets. Revenue £4.5bn up 5%; PBT £137m +9%; EPS 116.7 +9%; DPS 69p +2%' net debt £186m. At Kier trades on a FY19 PER of around 7.7x and offers a yield of c.7%
